elements.content: To make a porous material with high magnetic ordering temperature is challenging because the low density of the material is adverse to the dense magnetic moment, a prerequisite to high-performance magnets. Herein, we report a hollow magnetic metal–organic framework (MMOF) [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66] 1 (H2bpdc = 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid) with a Langmuir surface area of 1118 m2/g and spin-canted long-range magnetic ordering up to 22 K. Such a high performance is owing to the unique antiferromagnetic Kagomé lattice made of ferromagnetic Co3 clusters and conjugated 2,4,6-tri­(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligands, which is closely coupled with each other via double-interpenetration of the porous networks. Moreover, a parameter defined as the product of magnetic ordering/blocking temperature and the surface area for measuring the performance of porous molecular magnets is proposed.
elements.clean_text: To make a porous material with high magnetic ordering temperature is challenging because the low density of the material is adverse to the dense magnetic moment, a prerequisite to high-performance magnets. Herein, we report a hollow magnetic metal-organic framework (MMOF) [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66] 1 (H2bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid) with a Langmuir surface area of 1118 m2/g and spin-canted long-range magnetic ordering up to 22 K. Such a high performance is owing to the unique antiferromagnetic Kagomé lattice made of ferromagnetic Co3 clusters and conjugated 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligands, which is closely coupled with each other via double-interpenetration of the porous networks. Moreover, a parameter defined as the product of magnetic ordering/blocking temperature and the surface area for measuring the performance of porous molecular magnets is proposed.

elements.content: Combining permanent porosity and classic magnetic property at the molecular level has attracted much attention for creating multifunctional materials. Such materials, referred to as porous molecular magnets (PMMs), have potential applications in magnetic sensing and separation. However, to simultaneously obtain both high magnetic ordering temperature (T c) and large surface area is very challenging because poring the material inevitably reduces the collective movement of magnetic domains, and deceases T c. Hence, previous study of PMMs concentrate on inorganic solids or Prussian blue analogues for their strong magnetic interactions. Though T c of such materials can go up to the liquid nitrogen regime, the porosity of such compounds is rather limited.
elements.clean_text: Combining permanent porosity and classic magnetic property at the molecular level has attracted much attention for creating multifunctional materials. Such materials, referred to as porous molecular magnets (PMMs), have potential applications in magnetic sensing and separation. However, to simultaneously obtain both high magnetic ordering temperature (T c) and large surface area is very challenging because poring the material inevitably reduces the collective movement of magnetic domains, and deceases T c. Hence, previous study of PMMs concentrate on inorganic solids or Prussian blue analogues for their strong magnetic interactions. Though T c of such materials can go up to the liquid nitrogen regime, the porosity of such compounds is rather limited.

elements.content: In this regard, the diversities of ligand and metal ions in magnetic metal–organic frameworks (MMOFs) provide a fertile soil to explore this possibility. Pioneering work focuses on the design of inorganic layers, but later on more attention was paid to the organic linkers, especially for free radicals owing to their capacity to mediate strong magnetic interactions. Interestingly, frozen magnetization behavior, such as single-molecule magnet (SMM), single-chain magnet (SCM) and spin glass (SG) are also achieved in MMOFs, by especially sophisticated chemical design of secondary building units (SBUs). Furthermore, certain topological design such as the honeycomb, the Kagomé and the “Star” lattices introduces spin-frustration as well as porosity into the material, which meets our aim to build material with both high T c and large surface area.
elements.clean_text: In this regard, the diversities of ligand and metal ions in magnetic metal-organic frameworks (MMOFs) provide a fertile soil to explore this possibility. Pioneering work focuses on the design of inorganic layers, but later on more attention was paid to the organic linkers, especially for free radicals owing to their capacity to mediate strong magnetic interactions. Interestingly, frozen magnetization behavior, such as single-molecule magnet (SMM), single-chain magnet (SCM) and spin glass (SG) are also achieved in MMOFs, by especially sophisticated chemical design of secondary building units (SBUs). Furthermore, certain topological design such as the honeycomb, the Kagomé and the "Star" lattices introduces spin-frustration as well as porosity into the material, which meets our aim to build material with both high T c and large surface area.

elements.content: Herein, by the employment of 2,4,6-tri­(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligand as triangular template, we successfully integrate the ferromagnetic Co3 clusters into a Kagomé lattice, which is further pillared by 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate (bpdc) ligands to afford a three-dimensional (3D) MMOF [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66(DMF)2]·3DMF·2.5H2O [1·DMF2]·G. [1·DMF2]·G is very stable after desolvation, which affords the porous phase [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66] 1 with a large Langmuir surface area of 1118 m2/g and magnetic ordering up to 22 K.
elements.clean_text: Herein, by the employment of 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligand as triangular template, we successfully integrate the ferromagnetic Co3 clusters into a Kagomé lattice, which is further pillared by 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate (bpdc) ligands to afford a three-dimensional (3D) MMOF [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66(DMF)2]⋅3DMF⋅2.5H2O [1⋅DMF2]⋅G. [1⋅DMF2]⋅G is very stable after desolvation, which affords the porous phase [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66] 1 with a large Langmuir surface area of 1118 m2/g and magnetic ordering up to 22 K.

elements.content: X-ray single-crystal analysis shows that [1·DMF2]·G crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3̅c, and contains one and a half crystallographically independent Co­(II) ions in the Co3 SBU (a). Co1 occupies a centrosymmetric position and two centro-symmetry related Co2 atoms are bridged to Co1 via triple-carboxylate groups with Co···Co separation of 3.461 Å. Except for the carboxylate O atoms there is one O atom from a DMF solvent and one N atom from a tpt ligand coordinating to Co2. Each 3-connected tpt ligand coordinates to three Co3 SBUs, forming a Kagomé layer in the ab plane (d). Above and below the Kagomé layers the Co3 units also connect to each other via bpdc pillars (). These pillars extend along the c axis by π···π interaction between bpdc ligands (), forming a DNA-like double-helical chain, which screws along the 31 axes with a screw-pitch of 29.54 Å (). As the neighboring chains are screwing in the opposite direction, the Kagomé layers are hierarchically pillared by an ABC fashion along the c axis.
elements.clean_text: X-ray single-crystal analysis shows that [1⋅DMF2]⋅G crystallizes in the trigonal space group R3̅c, and contains one and a half crystallographically independent Co(II) ions in the Co3 SBU (a). Co1 occupies a centrosymmetric position and two centro-symmetry related Co2 atoms are bridged to Co1 via triple-carboxylate groups with Co⋅⋅⋅Co separation of 3.461 Å. Except for the carboxylate O atoms there is one O atom from a DMF solvent and one N atom from a tpt ligand coordinating to Co2. Each 3-connected tpt ligand coordinates to three Co3 SBUs, forming a Kagomé layer in the ab plane (d). Above and below the Kagomé layers the Co3 units also connect to each other via bpdc pillars (). These pillars extend along the c axis by π⋅⋅⋅π interaction between bpdc ligands (), forming a DNA-like double-helical chain, which screws along the 31 axes with a screw-pitch of 29.54 Å (). As the neighboring chains are screwing in the opposite direction, the Kagomé layers are hierarchically pillared by an ABC fashion along the c axis.

elements.content: (a) Structure of the Co3 SBU before and after activating. (b) (3, 6)-connected loh1 net. (c) 2-fold interpenetrating structure of [1·DMF2]·G. (d) Kagomé layers made of Co3 SBUs and tpt ligands and their ABC hierarchically packing mode. (e) and (f) Connectivity of cavities and channels of [1·DMF2]·G.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Structure of the Co3 SBU before and after activating. (b) (3, 6)-connected loh1 net. (c) 2-fold interpenetrating structure of [1⋅DMF2]⋅G. (d) Kagomé layers made of Co3 SBUs and tpt ligands and their ABC hierarchically packing mode. (e) and (f) Connectivity of cavities and channels of [1⋅DMF2]⋅G.

elements.content: The 3D structure of [1·DMF2]·G is thus a (3, 6)-connected network with the {43}2{46.66.83}3-loh1 topology (). There are two distinct cavities in this network. Cavity A is smaller, with 1.1 nm height, 1.5 nm diameter, and dicapped trigonal antiprism-shape, constructed by two [(Co3(COO)6)3(tpt)] triangles facing each other and nine pillars. Cavity B is larger, with 1.8 nm in height and 3.8 nm in diameter, constructed by two [(Co3(COO)6)3(tpt)] triangles, six Co3 SBUs and 18 pillars (b). However, there are two independent loh1 nets interpenetrating each other (c), affording only hollow cavity A in the structure. Remarkably, each cavity A connects to six neighboring cavity A via tubular channels (ca. 0.8 nm in length and 0.5 nm in diameter) constructed by the void space between carboxylic pillars, forming a 3D porous framework (e, f). Note that after interpenetrating the Kagomé layers in each net are closely stacked with each other via strong π···π interaction between tpt ligands (the shortest interlayer distance of 3.3 Å (d and ).
elements.clean_text: The 3D structure of [1⋅DMF2]⋅G is thus a (3, 6)-connected network with the {43}2{46.66.83}3-loh1 topology (). There are two distinct cavities in this network. Cavity A is smaller, with 1.1 nm height, 1.5 nm diameter, and dicapped trigonal antiprism-shape, constructed by two [(Co3(COO)6)3(tpt)] triangles facing each other and nine pillars. Cavity B is larger, with 1.8 nm in height and 3.8 nm in diameter, constructed by two [(Co3(COO)6)3(tpt)] triangles, six Co3 SBUs and 18 pillars (b). However, there are two independent loh1 nets interpenetrating each other (c), affording only hollow cavity A in the structure. Remarkably, each cavity A connects to six neighboring cavity A via tubular channels (ca. 0.8 nm in length and 0.5 nm in diameter) constructed by the void space between carboxylic pillars, forming a 3D porous framework (e, f). Note that after interpenetrating the Kagomé layers in each net are closely stacked with each other via strong π⋅⋅⋅π interaction between tpt ligands (the shortest interlayer distance of 3.3 Å (d and ).

elements.content: The TGA curve of [1·DMF2]·G displays a gradual weight loss of 26.4% from 25 to 220 °C. Associating with element analysis, the weight lose corresponds to the release of 5 DMF molecules and 2.5 H2O per formula unit (). A Plateau observed from 220 to 340 °C indicates the stability of the solvent-free framework. Hence, the desolvated phase 1 was obtained by soaking [1·DMF2]·G in CH2Cl2 and activated at 150 °C over 12 h under vacuum. The PXRD experiment of 1 show amorphous phase. However, after soaking this amorphous powder in fresh DMF for several days, the crystallinity recovered and the PXRD pattern agreed with the simulating result, indicating the preserve of the framework after activating (). Significantly, the terminal Co2 ions change from six-coordinate to five-coordinate due to the loss of DMF molecules (a), which is accompanied by the color change from reddish orange to dark purple (, inset). The removal of coordinating DMF was confirmed by IR spectrum for the absence of CO stretching vibration (1651 cm–1) and C–N stretching vibration (1255 and 1092 cm–1) after activation (), whereas the Raman spectra note the unaltered coordinating COO– groups (), confirming the preserve of the framework during activation.
elements.clean_text: The TGA curve of [1⋅DMF2]⋅G displays a gradual weight loss of 26.4% from 25 to 220 °C. Associating with element analysis, the weight lose corresponds to the release of 5 DMF molecules and 2.5 H2O per formula unit (). A Plateau observed from 220 to 340 °C indicates the stability of the solvent-free framework. Hence, the desolvated phase 1 was obtained by soaking [1⋅DMF2]⋅G in CH2Cl2 and activated at 150 °C over 12 h under vacuum. The PXRD experiment of 1 show amorphous phase. However, after soaking this amorphous powder in fresh DMF for several days, the crystallinity recovered and the PXRD pattern agreed with the simulating result, indicating the preserve of the framework after activating (). Significantly, the terminal Co2 ions change from six-coordinate to five-coordinate due to the loss of DMF molecules (a), which is accompanied by the color change from reddish orange to dark purple (, inset). The removal of coordinating DMF was confirmed by IR spectrum for the absence of CO stretching vibration (1651 cm-1) and C-N stretching vibration (1255 and 1092 cm-1) after activation (), whereas the Raman spectra note the unaltered coordinating COO- groups (), confirming the preserve of the framework during activation.

elements.content: The N2 sorption isotherm of 1 shows a Type-I behavior (a). In the low-pressure region, a fast increase in N2 undertake up to 190 cm3 g–1 (STP) attributes to the monolayer adsorption, indicating micropore-type sorption. N2 uptaking increases slowly in the middle pressure region, whereas in the high pressure region, a sharp increase is observed and further reaches the maximum uptake of 319 cm3 g–1 at 1 bar, which may result from capillary condensation and/or the flexible nature of 1 after activating. For desorption, a hysteresis in high pressure region is observed, also suggesting the flexible nature of the framework. The Langmuir surface area is calculated to be 1118 m2/g. The total pore volume is determined to be 0.47 cm3/g, which agrees well with the simulating result of 0.58 cm3/g from single-crystal data by removing the coordinating solvent from [1·DMF2]·G.
elements.clean_text: The N2 sorption isotherm of 1 shows a Type-I behavior (a). In the low-pressure region, a fast increase in N2 undertake up to 190 cm3 g-1 (STP) attributes to the monolayer adsorption, indicating micropore-type sorption. N2 uptaking increases slowly in the middle pressure region, whereas in the high pressure region, a sharp increase is observed and further reaches the maximum uptake of 319 cm3 g-1 at 1 bar, which may result from capillary condensation and/or the flexible nature of 1 after activating. For desorption, a hysteresis in high pressure region is observed, also suggesting the flexible nature of the framework. The Langmuir surface area is calculated to be 1118 m2/g. The total pore volume is determined to be 0.47 cm3/g, which agrees well with the simulating result of 0.58 cm3/g from single-crystal data by removing the coordinating solvent from [1⋅DMF2]⋅G.

elements.content: (a) N2 adsorption isotherm of 1 at 77 K. Insert, CO2 sorption at 273 and 298 K. (b) Isosteric heat plots with low CO2 loading. Inset, CO2 and CH4 sorption at 298 K and IAST predicted selectivity for CO2/CH4.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) N2 adsorption isotherm of 1 at 77 K. Insert, CO2 sorption at 273 and 298 K. (b) Isosteric heat plots with low CO2 loading. Inset, CO2 and CH4 sorption at 298 K and IAST predicted selectivity for CO2/CH4.

elements.content: The CO2 uptake under 1 bar is 55 cm3 g–1 (STP) at 273 K and 28 cm3 g–1 at 298 K, respectively (a, inset). By fitting the two isotherms with the virial-type expression, the zero-coverage isosteric heat of adsorption is determined to be 26.0 kJ mol–1, indicating weak interactions between CO2 and the MOFs. Furthermore, the selective adsorption for equimolar CO2/CH4 mixture can be obtained from the single-component isotherms of CO2 and CH4 (b, inset) using ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST). The selectivity is 4.4 at 100 kPa, which is comparable with some ZIFs.
elements.clean_text: The CO2 uptake under 1 bar is 55 cm3 g-1 (STP) at 273 K and 28 cm3 g-1 at 298 K, respectively (a, inset). By fitting the two isotherms with the virial-type expression, the zero-coverage isosteric heat of adsorption is determined to be 26.0 kJ mol-1, indicating weak interactions between CO2 and the MOFs. Furthermore, the selective adsorption for equimolar CO2/CH4 mixture can be obtained from the single-component isotherms of CO2 and CH4 (b, inset) using ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST). The selectivity is 4.4 at 100 kPa, which is comparable with some ZIFs.

elements.content: To investigate the adsorption mechanism, grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMS) simulations were performed to obtain the enthalpy of adsorption and host–guest interactions mode. The energy of host–guest interaction is ca. 27.6 kJ mol–1, which is in good agreement with the above experimental value. The simulation reveals that CO2 molecules only interact with the framework in the position near the terminal Co­(II) ions and around the double-helical chain (). Surprisingly, the cavity does not show any strong interaction sites, which explains the moderate adsorption of CO2 in 1.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the adsorption mechanism, grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMS) simulations were performed to obtain the enthalpy of adsorption and host-guest interactions mode. The energy of host-guest interaction is ca. 27.6 kJ mol-1, which is in good agreement with the above experimental value. The simulation reveals that CO2 molecules only interact with the framework in the position near the terminal Co(II) ions and around the double-helical chain (). Surprisingly, the cavity does not show any strong interaction sites, which explains the moderate adsorption of CO2 in 1.

elements.content: Temperature-dependent direct-current (dc) susceptibility data for 1 was collected at a magnetic field of 1.0 kOe over the temperature range 2–300 K (a). At room temperature, the χM T product is 11.35 cm3 K mol–1, significantly higher than three uncoupled spin-only Co­(II) ions (5.61 cm3 K mol–1 for s = 3/2 and g = 2.0) because of the orbital contribution of Co­(II) ions. Upon cooling, χM T decreases first, and then rapidly rises to a maximum of 51.70 cm3 K mol–1 at 28 K. The rise could be attributed to the compensation of the residual magnetization in virtue of spin-canted antiferromagnetism which is also suggested by the strong field-dependent χM vs T curves at low temperatures ().
elements.clean_text: Temperature-dependent direct-current (dc) susceptibility data for 1 was collected at a magnetic field of 1.0 kOe over the temperature range 2-300 K (a). At room temperature, the χM T product is 11.35 cm3 K mol-1, significantly higher than three uncoupled spin-only Co(II) ions (5.61 cm3 K mol-1 for s = 3/2 and g = 2.0) because of the orbital contribution of Co(II) ions. Upon cooling, χM T decreases first, and then rapidly rises to a maximum of 51.70 cm3 K mol-1 at 28 K. The rise could be attributed to the compensation of the residual magnetization in virtue of spin-canted antiferromagnetism which is also suggested by the strong field-dependent χM vs T curves at low temperatures ().

elements.content: (a) χM T versus T plot for 1 under 1000 Oe dc field. The solid line is the best fit. Insert, the magnetic exchange-coupling pathways in the Kagomé layer. The arrows indicate the potential magnetic structure in 1. (b) Magnetic hysteresis loops for 1 at indicated temperatures. Inset, the FC and ZFC plots under 50 Oe dc field (down); the local enlargement of magnetic hysteresis (top).
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) χM T versus T plot for 1 under 1000 Oe dc field. The solid line is the best fit. Insert, the magnetic exchange-coupling pathways in the Kagomé layer. The arrows indicate the potential magnetic structure in 1. (b) Magnetic hysteresis loops for 1 at indicated temperatures. Inset, the FC and ZFC plots under 50 Oe dc field (down); the local enlargement of magnetic hysteresis (top).

elements.content: The zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) magnetization data measured under 50 Oe reveal a clear divergence at 22 K for 1 (b, inset), indicative of a transition from paramagnetic state to irreversible magnetic state. A classic hysteresis for 1 can be observed at the temperature up to 18 K (). As the temperature decreasing, the remnant magnetization and coercivity come to largest value of 0.48 μB and 5600 Oe at 10 K (b). In addition, the magnetization at 2.0 K increases rapidly in low field but slowly in high field (), finally reaches 4.89 μB for 1 at 7 T, which is far below the saturation, indicating the presence of spin-canting behavior. The hysteresis at 10 K gives a remnant magnetization of 0.48 μB. Thus, the canting angle is calculated to be 3.06° according to sin­(α) = M R/M S (for g = 2.00).
elements.clean_text: The zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) magnetization data measured under 50 Oe reveal a clear divergence at 22 K for 1 (b, inset), indicative of a transition from paramagnetic state to irreversible magnetic state. A classic hysteresis for 1 can be observed at the temperature up to 18 K (). As the temperature decreasing, the remnant magnetization and coercivity come to largest value of 0.48 μB and 5600 Oe at 10 K (b). In addition, the magnetization at 2.0 K increases rapidly in low field but slowly in high field (), finally reaches 4.89 μB for 1 at 7 T, which is far below the saturation, indicating the presence of spin-canting behavior. The hysteresis at 10 K gives a remnant magnetization of 0.48 μB. Thus, the canting angle is calculated to be 3.06° according to sin(α) = M R/M S (for g = 2.00).

elements.content: Alternating-current (ac) susceptibility measurements were carried out under zero dc field (). For 1, the temperature-dependence of the in-phase (χ′) and out-of-phase (χ″) ac susceptibilities exhibit frequency-dependent regions. The relaxation shifts the χ″ maximum from 18.7 K at 1 Hz to 24.2 K at 1218 Hz. Fitting the Arrhenius law, τ = τ0exp­(U eff/k B T) (), where U eff is the average energy barrier for the reversal of the magnetization, τ0 is the attempt time and k B is the Boltzmann constant, gives U eff = 581.4 K and τ0 = 5.46 × 10–15 s. The value of τ0 is much lower than that for a superparamagnetic system (usually 1 × 10–8 to 1 × 10–12 s), ruling out the superparamagnetic behavior. Moreover, the parameter φ = (ΔT p/T p)/Δ­(logf), is estimated as 0.05, falling into the range of a spin glass.
elements.clean_text: Alternating-current (ac) susceptibility measurements were carried out under zero dc field (). For 1, the temperature-dependence of the in-phase (χ') and out-of-phase (χ") ac susceptibilities exhibit frequency-dependent regions. The relaxation shifts the χ" maximum from 18.7 K at 1 Hz to 24.2 K at 1218 Hz. Fitting the Arrhenius law, τ = τ0exp(U eff/k B T) (), where U eff is the average energy barrier for the reversal of the magnetization, τ0 is the attempt time and k B is the Boltzmann constant, gives U eff = 581.4 K and τ0 = 5.46 × 10-15 s. The value of τ0 is much lower than that for a superparamagnetic system (usually 1 × 10-8 to 1 × 10-12 s), ruling out the superparamagnetic behavior. Moreover, the parameter φ = (ΔT p/T p)/Δ(logf), is estimated as 0.05, falling into the range of a spin glass.

elements.content: To analyze this phenomenon the dc susceptibility data are further modeled by using the following Hamiltonian Ĥ = Ĥ Co , i + Ĥ ex + Ĥ KL where Ĥ Co, i is for the single Co­(II) ions in the T 1g states, Ĥ ex represents the exchange within the Co3 SBU and Ĥ KL is for the magnetic exchange in Kagomé layer. Each Hamiltonian expands as follows Ĥ Co , i = Δ i ( L̂ i , z 2 − 2 3 ) − 3 2 κ i λ i L̂ i Ŝ i + β H u [ − 3 2 κ i L̂ i , u + g e Ŝ i , u ] ( i = 1 , 2 ; u = z , x ) Ĥ ex = − J 1 ( Ŝ 1 Ŝ 2 + Ŝ 1 Ŝ 2 a ) Ĥ KL = − J 2 ∑ j , k Ŝ Co 3 , j · Ŝ Co 3 , k The fit program combines the linear Co3 model with Kagomé lattice, including the parameters of spin–orbit coupling parameter (λ), the orbital reduction factor (κ) and the axial splitting parameter (Δ) for the local Co­(II) ions, the exchange coupling (J 1) between Co­(II) ions in Co3 unit, and the magnetic interactions (J 2) between Co3 units in a Kagomé layer transmitted by tpt ligand (a, inset). The best fitting of the magnetic data above 80 K for 1 leads to J 1 = 7.8 cm–1, J 2 = −0.57 cm–1, λ1 = −128 cm–1, κ1 = 0.93, Δ1 = −1821 cm–1 (for Co1), and λ2 = −94 cm–1, κ2 = 0.93, Δ2 = 822 cm–1 (for Co2′). The distinct axial splitting parameters are due to the different coordination environments of the two Co­(II) ions: six-coordinating for Co1 and five-coordinating for Co2′; the positive J 1 value indicates ferromagnetic interaction between Co­(II) ions in the linear Co3 unit, which is similar to these of Co3 compounds with carboxylate bridges; and the small negative J 2 indicates weak antiferromagnetic interaction mediated through the tpt bridge.
elements.clean_text: To analyze this phenomenon the dc susceptibility data are further modeled by using the following Hamiltonian 1    Ĥ =   Ĥ   Co , i   +   Ĥ   ex   +   Ĥ   KL     where Ĥ Co, i is for the single Co(II) ions in the T 1g  states, Ĥ ex represents the exchange within the Co3 SBU and Ĥ KL is for the magnetic exchange in Kagomé layer. Each Hamiltonian expands as follows 2      Ĥ   Co , i   =   Δ   i    (   L̂   i , z   2   -   2   3   )  -   3   2     κ   i     λ   i     L̂   i     Ŝ   i   + β   H   u    [ -   3   2     κ   i     L̂   i , u   +   g   e     Ŝ   i , u   ]    ( i = 1 , 2 ; u = z , x )      3      Ĥ   ex   = -   J   1    (   Ŝ   1     Ŝ   2   +   Ŝ   1     Ŝ   2 a   )      4      Ĥ   KL   = -   J   2     ∑   j , k     Ŝ     Co   3   , j   ⋅   Ŝ     Co   3   , k     The fit program combines the linear Co3 model with Kagomé lattice, including the parameters of spin-orbit coupling parameter (λ), the orbital reduction factor (κ) and the axial splitting parameter (Δ) for the local Co(II) ions, the exchange coupling (J 1) between Co(II) ions in Co3 unit, and the magnetic interactions (J 2) between Co3 units in a Kagomé layer transmitted by tpt ligand (a, inset). The best fitting of the magnetic data above 80 K for 1 leads to J 1 = 7.8 cm-1, J 2 = -0.57 cm-1, λ1 = -128 cm-1, κ1 = 0.93, Δ1 = -1821 cm-1 (for Co1), and λ2 = -94 cm-1, κ2 = 0.93, Δ2 = 822 cm-1 (for Co2'). The distinct axial splitting parameters are due to the different coordination environments of the two Co(II) ions: six-coordinating for Co1 and five-coordinating for Co2'; the positive J 1 value indicates ferromagnetic interaction between Co(II) ions in the linear Co3 unit, which is similar to these of Co3 compounds with carboxylate bridges; and the small negative J 2 indicates weak antiferromagnetic interaction mediated through the tpt bridge.

elements.content: The above analysis indicates the magnetism of 1 is dominated by single-ion magnetic anisotropy of the Co­(II) ions, which further coupled by the distinct intra and inter magnetic couplings of the Co3 clusters. The antiferromagnetic magnetic interactions between the corner Co­(II) ions compete the ferromagnetic interaction with the central Co­(II) ion. The latter tries to align the adjacent spins parallel, while the former fits to the frustrated scheme of the triangular lattice (see inset in a). Hence, competing magnetic interactions, together with the single-ion magnetic anisotropy of the Co­(II) ions, induce the glassy behavior of 1. Moreover, because of linear Co3 units tilting to the ab plane (17.66°), which leads to a wave-like Kagomé layer, Dzyaloshinskii–Moriya (DM) interactions can be induced in favor of the lack of an inversion center between adjacent Co3 units. Along with the magnetic anisotropy for Co­(II) ions, spin canting and a net moment occur in the antiferromagnetic Kagomé layers. The close interlayer interactions can then generate a canted antiferromagnetic ordering below 22 K, but without a complete suppression of spin frustration. As such, the coexsitence of the canted long-range magnetic order and spin-glass behavior resulted, which was previously observed in Kagomé antiferromagents. According to the classification of molecule-based magnetic materials, the material can be described using symbol M3U2S3.
elements.clean_text: The above analysis indicates the magnetism of 1 is dominated by single-ion magnetic anisotropy of the Co(II) ions, which further coupled by the distinct intra and inter magnetic couplings of the Co3 clusters. The antiferromagnetic magnetic interactions between the corner Co(II) ions compete the ferromagnetic interaction with the central Co(II) ion. The latter tries to align the adjacent spins parallel, while the former fits to the frustrated scheme of the triangular lattice (see inset in a). Hence, competing magnetic interactions, together with the single-ion magnetic anisotropy of the Co(II) ions, induce the glassy behavior of 1. Moreover, because of linear Co3 units tilting to the ab plane (17.66°), which leads to a wave-like Kagomé layer, Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya (DM) interactions can be induced in favor of the lack of an inversion center between adjacent Co3 units. Along with the magnetic anisotropy for Co(II) ions, spin canting and a net moment occur in the antiferromagnetic Kagomé layers. The close interlayer interactions can then generate a canted antiferromagnetic ordering below 22 K, but without a complete suppression of spin frustration. As such, the coexsitence of the canted long-range magnetic order and spin-glass behavior resulted, which was previously observed in Kagomé antiferromagents. According to the classification of molecule-based magnetic materials, the material can be described using symbol M3U2S3.

elements.content: It should be noted that magnetic behavior of MMOFs is complicated, especially because of the solvent and guest molecules. To quantify the performance of an MMOF, a parameter A is defined here A = T × S where T represents T c or magnetic blocking temperature (T B) and S is the surface area (preferred using Langmuir data). The larger A is, the better performance the MMOF has. As summarized in , the A value of 1 is in the top 2 place in reported MMOFs, which is very high if compared to other compounds. Moreover, we can discern that magnetic ordering/blocking in MMOFs show much different T c with/without guests from this Table. Specifically, the highest T c of 105 K for MMOFs decreases five folds when removing the guests; the maximum T c for a series of guest-exchange MMOFs is ten times higher than the desolvated framework; SMM12 or SCM13 behaviors disappear after activating the MMOFs. Interestingly, T c of the parental solvated compound [1·DMF2]·G (21 K) is almost the same to that of 1 (), verifying the intrinsic nature of the framework.

To quantify the performance of an MMOF, a parameter A is defined here    A = T × S   where T represents T c or magnetic blocking temperature (T B) and S is the surface area (preferred using Langmuir data). The larger A is, the better performance the MMOF has. As summarized in , the A value of 1 is in the top 2 place in reported MMOFs, which is very high if compared to other compounds. Moreover, we can discern that magnetic ordering/blocking in MMOFs show much different T c with/without guests from this Table. Specifically, the highest T c of 105 K for MMOFs decreases five folds when removing the guests; the maximum T c for a series of guest-exchange MMOFs is ten times higher than the desolvated framework; SMM12 or SCM13 behaviors disappear after activating the MMOFs. Interestingly, T c of the parental solvated compound [1⋅DMF2]⋅G (21 K) is almost the same to that of 1 (), verifying the intrinsic nature of the framework.

elements.content:
Performance of Representative MMOFs complex S (m2 g–1) T solvated (K) T desolvated (K) A (m2 g–1 K) ref (Me2NH2)2[Fe2L3] 1175 105 26 30550 , [Co3(bpdc)6tpt0.66] 1118 21 22 24596 Here [Fe3(HCOO)6] 385 16.1 16.1 6198 [Co3(lac)2(pybz)2] 1050 32 3 3150 [Co(Tt)2][Cu6(5-mip)6] 1217 10.5 [Co2(H0.67bdt)3] 833 1.8 [KCo7(OH)3(ip)6] 513 2

Langmuir surface area.

BET surface area.

H2L 2,5-dichloro-3,6-dihydroxy-1,4-benzoquinone.

lac = D- and L-lactate, pybz = 4-pyridyl benzoate.

Tt = tris­(triazolyl)­borate, 5-mip = 5-methylisophthalate.

H2bdt = 5,5′-(1,4-phenylene)­bis­(1H-tetrazole).

ip = isophthalate.

In summary, by assembling the linear Co3 SBUs with ferromagnetic state and the rigid triangular tpt ligands a geometrically frustrated Kagomé lattice is successfully integrated into a 3D MMOF, which ensures a relatively strong magnetic exchange-coupling in 1. Moreover, by using the long pillaring dicarboxylate ligands a unique 2-fold interpenetrating network with large surface area is also achieved. Hence, the A value of 1 is very high in reported MMOFs. This cooperative ligand strategy may open a new way to rational design multifunctional materials, especially for high-performance PMMs based on the platform of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: In summary, by assembling the linear Co3 SBUs with ferromagnetic state and the rigid triangular tpt ligands a geometrically frustrated Kagomé lattice is successfully integrated into a 3D MMOF, which ensures a relatively strong magnetic exchange-coupling in 1. Moreover, by using the long pillaring dicarboxylate ligands a unique 2-fold interpenetrating network with large surface area is also achieved. Hence, the A value of 1 is very high in reported MMOFs. This cooperative ligand strategy may open a new way to rational design multifunctional materials, especially for high-performance PMMs based on the platform of MOFs.

cln_elements.content:
To make a porous material with high magnetic ordering temperature is challenging because the low density of the material is adverse to the dense magnetic moment, a prerequisite to high-performance magnets. Herein, we report a hollow magnetic metal–organic framework (MMOF) [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66] 1 (H2bpdc = 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid) with a Langmuir surface area of 1118 m2/g and spin-canted long-range magnetic ordering up to 22 K. Such a high performance is owing to the unique antiferromagnetic Kagomé lattice made of ferromagnetic Co3 clusters and conjugated 2,4,6-tri­(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligands, which is closely coupled with each other via double-interpenetration of the porous networks. Moreover, a parameter defined as the product of magnetic ordering/blocking temperature and the surface area for measuring the performance of porous molecular magnets is proposed.

Herein, by the employment of 2,4,6-tri­(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligand as triangular template, we successfully integrate the ferromagnetic Co3 clusters into a Kagomé lattice, which is further pillared by 4,4′-biphenyldicarboxylate (bpdc) ligands to afford a three-dimensional (3D) MMOF [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66(DMF)2]·3DMF·2.5H2O [1·DMF2]·G. [1·DMF2]·G is very stable after desolvation, which affords the porous phase [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66] 1 with a large Langmuir surface area of 1118 m2/g and magnetic ordering up to 22 K.

The TGA curve of [1·DMF2]·G displays a gradual weight loss of 26.4% from 25 to 220 °C. Associating with element analysis, the weight lose corresponds to the release of 5 DMF molecules and 2.5 H2O per formula unit (). A Plateau observed from 220 to 340 °C indicates the stability of the solvent-free framework. Hence, the desolvated phase 1 was obtained by soaking [1·DMF2]·G in CH2Cl2 and activated at 150 °C over 12 h under vacuum. The PXRD experiment of 1 show amorphous phase. However, after soaking this amorphous powder in fresh DMF for several days, the crystallinity recovered and the PXRD pattern agreed with the simulating result, indicating the preserve of the framework after activating (). Significantly, the terminal Co2 ions change from six-coordinate to five-coordinate due to the loss of DMF molecules (a), which is accompanied by the color change from reddish orange to dark purple (, inset). The removal of coordinating DMF was confirmed by IR spectrum for the absence of CO stretching vibration (1651 cm–1) and C–N stretching vibration (1255 and 1092 cm–1) after activation (), whereas the Raman spectra note the unaltered coordinating COO– groups (), confirming the preserve of the framework during activation.

The N2 sorption isotherm of 1 shows a Type-I behavior (a). In the low-pressure region, a fast increase in N2 undertake up to 190 cm3 g–1 (STP) attributes to the monolayer adsorption, indicating micropore-type sorption. N2 uptaking increases slowly in the middle pressure region, whereas in the high pressure region, a sharp increase is observed and further reaches the maximum uptake of 319 cm3 g–1 at 1 bar, which may result from capillary condensation and/or the flexible nature of 1 after activating. For desorption, a hysteresis in high pressure region is observed, also suggesting the flexible nature of the framework. The Langmuir surface area is calculated to be 1118 m2/g. The total pore volume is determined to be 0.47 cm3/g, which agrees well with the simulating result of 0.58 cm3/g from single-crystal data by removing the coordinating solvent from [1·DMF2]·G.

The CO2 uptake under 1 bar is 55 cm3 g–1 (STP) at 273 K and 28 cm3 g–1 at 298 K, respectively (a, inset). By fitting the two isotherms with the virial-type expression, the zero-coverage isosteric heat of adsorption is determined to be 26.0 kJ mol–1, indicating weak interactions between CO2 and the MOFs. Furthermore, the selective adsorption for equimolar CO2/CH4 mixture can be obtained from the single-component isotherms of CO2 and CH4 (b, inset) using ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST). The selectivity is 4.4 at 100 kPa, which is comparable with some ZIFs.

Temperature-dependent direct-current (dc) susceptibility data for 1 was collected at a magnetic field of 1.0 kOe over the temperature range 2–300 K (a). At room temperature, the χM T product is 11.35 cm3 K mol–1, significantly higher than three uncoupled spin-only Co­(II) ions (5.61 cm3 K mol–1 for s = 3/2 and g = 2.0) because of the orbital contribution of Co­(II) ions. Upon cooling, χM T decreases first, and then rapidly rises to a maximum of 51.70 cm3 K mol–1 at 28 K. The rise could be attributed to the compensation of the residual magnetization in virtue of spin-canted antiferromagnetism which is also suggested by the strong field-dependent χM vs T curves at low temperatures ().

The zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) magnetization data measured under 50 Oe reveal a clear divergence at 22 K for 1 (b, inset), indicative of a transition from paramagnetic state to irreversible magnetic state. A classic hysteresis for 1 can be observed at the temperature up to 18 K (). As the temperature decreasing, the remnant magnetization and coercivity come to largest value of 0.48 μB and 5600 Oe at 10 K (b). In addition, the magnetization at 2.0 K increases rapidly in low field but slowly in high field (), finally reaches 4.89 μB for 1 at 7 T, which is far below the saturation, indicating the presence of spin-canting behavior. The hysteresis at 10 K gives a remnant magnetization of 0.48 μB. Thus, the canting angle is calculated to be 3.06° according to sin­(α) = M R/M S (for g = 2.00).

To make a porous material with high magnetic ordering temperature is challenging because the low density of the material is adverse to the dense magnetic moment, a prerequisite to high-performance magnets. Herein, we report a hollow magnetic metal-organic framework (MMOF) [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66] 1 (H2bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid) with a Langmuir surface area of 1118 m2/g and spin-canted long-range magnetic ordering up to 22 K. Such a high performance is owing to the unique antiferromagnetic Kagomé lattice made of ferromagnetic Co3 clusters and conjugated 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligands, which is closely coupled with each other via double-interpenetration of the porous networks. Moreover, a parameter defined as the product of magnetic ordering/blocking temperature and the surface area for measuring the performance of porous molecular magnets is proposed.

Herein, by the employment of 2,4,6-tri(4-pyridinyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) ligand as triangular template, we successfully integrate the ferromagnetic Co3 clusters into a Kagomé lattice, which is further pillared by 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate (bpdc) ligands to afford a three-dimensional (3D) MMOF [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66(DMF)2]⋅3DMF⋅2.5H2O [1⋅DMF2]⋅G. [1⋅DMF2]⋅G is very stable after desolvation, which affords the porous phase [Co3(bpdc)3(tpt)0.66] 1 with a large Langmuir surface area of 1118 m2/g and magnetic ordering up to 22 K.

The TGA curve of [1⋅DMF2]⋅G displays a gradual weight loss of 26.4% from 25 to 220 °C. Associating with element analysis, the weight lose corresponds to the release of 5 DMF molecules and 2.5 H2O per formula unit (). Hence, the desolvated phase 1 was obtained by soaking [1⋅DMF2]⋅G in CH2Cl2 and activated at 150 °C over 12 h under vacuum. The PXRD experiment of 1 show amorphous phase. However, after soaking this amorphous powder in fresh DMF for several days, the crystallinity recovered and the PXRD pattern agreed with the simulating result, indicating the preserve of the framework after activating (). The removal of coordinating DMF was confirmed by IR spectrum for the absence of CO stretching vibration (1651 cm-1) and C-N stretching vibration (1255 and 1092 cm-1) after activation (), whereas the Raman spectra note the unaltered coordinating COO- groups (), confirming the preserve of the framework during activation.

The N2 sorption isotherm of 1 shows a Type-I behavior (a). In the low-pressure region, a fast increase in N2 undertake up to 190 cm3 g-1 (STP) attributes to the monolayer adsorption, indicating micropore-type sorption. N2 uptaking increases slowly in the middle pressure region, whereas in the high pressure region, a sharp increase is observed and further reaches the maximum uptake of 319 cm3 g-1 at 1 bar, which may result from capillary condensation and/or the flexible nature of 1 after activating. For desorption, a hysteresis in high pressure region is observed, also suggesting the flexible nature of the framework. The Langmuir surface area is calculated to be 1118 m2/g. The total pore volume is determined to be 0.47 cm3/g, which agrees well with the simulating result of 0.58 cm3/g from single-crystal data by removing the coordinating solvent from [1⋅DMF2]⋅G.

The CO2 uptake under 1 bar is 55 cm3 g-1 (STP) at 273 K and 28 cm3 g-1 at 298 K, respectively (a, inset). By fitting the two isotherms with the virial-type expression, the zero-coverage isosteric heat of adsorption is determined to be 26.0 kJ mol-1, indicating weak interactions between CO2 and the MOFs. The selectivity is 4.4 at 100 kPa, which is comparable with some ZIFs. 

Temperature-dependent direct-current (dc) susceptibility data for 1 was collected at a magnetic field of 1.0 kOe over the temperature range 2-300 K (a). At room temperature, the χM T product is 11.35 cm3 K mol-1, significantly higher than three uncoupled spin-only Co(II) ions (5.61 cm3 K mol-1 for s = 3/2 and g = 2.0) because of the orbital contribution of Co(II) ions. Upon cooling, χM T decreases first, and then rapidly rises to a maximum of 51.70 cm3 K mol-1 at 28 K. The rise could be attributed to the compensation of the residual magnetization in virtue of spin-canted antiferromagnetism which is also suggested by the strong field-dependent χM vs T curves at low temperatures ().

The zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) magnetization data measured under 50 Oe reveal a clear divergence at 22 K for 1 (b, inset), indicative of a transition from paramagnetic state to irreversible magnetic state. A classic hysteresis for 1 can be observed at the temperature up to 18 K (). As the temperature decreasing, the remnant magnetization and coercivity come to largest value of 0.48 μB and 5600 Oe at 10 K (b). In addition, the magnetization at 2.0 K increases rapidly in low field but slowly in high field (), finally reaches 4.89 μB for 1 at 7 T, which is far below the saturation, indicating the presence of spin-canting behavior. The hysteresis at 10 K gives a remnant magnetization of 0.48 μB. Thus, the canting angle is calculated to be 3.06° according to sin(α) = M R/M S (for g = 2.00).

gas adsorption.condition: capillary condensation and/or the flexible nature of 1 after activating

| (Me<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>[Fe<sub>2</sub>L<sub>3</sub>]<sup>a</sup> | 1175 | 105 | 26 | 30550 | [10], [11] |

metadata.title:
Cobalt(II) Magnetic Metal–Organic Framework
with an Effective Kagomé Lattice, Large Surface Area, and High
Spin-Canted Ordering Temperature
